newsitem.title: UK: Dollar pauses in late Europe after dash to highs.
newsitem.headline: Dollar pauses in late Europe after dash to highs.

text.p: The dollar was off its early 71-month peak in late Europe, but analysts said the weak-mark story which has catapulted it higher was set to run and run.

The dollar was also cheered by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who painted an upbeat picture of the U.S. economy in his closely-watched Humphrey Hawkins testimony last night and sent U.S. stocks and bonds soaring.

"The market's been very pleased by Greenspan's comments generally and that contrast with what's happening in Europe means the dollar is a great thing at the moment," said Elizabeth Legge, chief economist at Bankgesellschaft Berlin in London.

The U.S. unit hit a new peak of 1.8325 marks in early Europe, way up from late Tuesday's level of 1.8168/78. By 1525 GMT it had slipped back to 1.8255/60, stung partly by a comment from Fed Vice Chair Alice Rivlin that the dollar may not get much stronger.
Earlier, Rivlin warned the House Banking Committee of the risk of higher inflation and said the decision on whether to raise interest rates further was a "tough call".
Though that unsettled the asset markets, traders said the dollar was unfazed by the prospect of higher U.S. rates, which would increase its appeal in terms of yield.
There was also little forex reaction to assertions by the Fed's Laurence Meyer and William McDonough that the U.S. central bank should take preemptive action against inflation.

The ever-growing conviction that European monetary union will be launched on time by a wide group of countries -- ushering in a weak euro -- saw the mark sold heavily again, especially for currencies perceived as non-EMU safe havens.
The mark dived to more than seven-year lows against sterling, its weakest level against the Swedish crown since December 1992, and an 11-month low against the Swiss franc.
Analysts foresaw precious little respite for the mark.
"As long as the market perceives the euro's going to be soft, this trend is going to continue," said Nick Stamenkovic, economist at DKB International here.
"I don't think there's much the authorities can do to change the mark's downward trend against the dollar."
Mark/yen slumped to a two-year low of 62.93 during the session, down from late Tuesday's 63.56/58, but recovered to an intraday high of 63.45/48 by 1541 GMT.
Traders said that hauled dollar/yen up too, to trade at 115.74/84 versus yesterday's close of 115.52/57. But dollar/yen remains sidelined by what is basically a mark-led move.
Although speculation of central bank intervention to brake the mark's decline circulated in the market, traders said it was less prevalent than last week, when dollar/mark was hovering near 1.80.

There was some talk in the market that the Bundesbank might revert to a variable-rate repo after Thursday's regular council meeting, offering support to the mark by flagging the prospect of higher German rates.
But analysts were doubtful, and some said even a switch to a variable repo would have limited impact since EMU, not German interest rate levels, had been the principal mark-negative.
The mark's slide against the Swiss franc helped dollar/Swiss climb to an over four-month high of 1.4900 during the session. It stood at 1.4840/50 at 1609 GMT versus late Tuesday's 1.4803/08.
